item.title: [Talk] Quantum invariants of framed links from cohomology of self-distributive structures
item.description:
Speaker: Emanuele Zappala

Time: 2:00pm, Thursday, June 4

Abstract: In this talk I will give a brief introduction to knot theory and the notion of knot invariant. Next I will describe the process of algebraization of knot theory which naturally gives Yang-Baxter operators, Yetter-Drinfeld modules and racks/quandles etc. After recalling the definition of cohomology of racks, I will proceed to show how to construct an invariant of links and knotted surfaces from cocycles. I will therefore explain some recent joint works with M. Elhamdadi and M. Saito relating self-distributivity of higher arity structures and invariants of framed links, with a (categorical) perspective on how to realize them as quantum invariants.

Zoom links: click me.

item.title: [Talk] Compressed Sensing
item.description:
Title: Compressed Sensing.

Speaker: Vasile Pop.

Date: Thursday, February 27th, 2020

Place: CIS 1045

Abstract: Compressed sensing (CS) is an exciting, rapidly growing field that has attracted considerable attention in statistics, applied mathematics, electrical engineering and computer science. CS offers a framework for simultaneous sensing and compression of finite/infinite dimensional vectors, that relies on linear dimensionality reduction. The restricted isometry property (RIP) is at the center of important developments in compressive sensing. In $\Bbb R^n$, RIP establishes the success of sparse recovery via basis pursuit for measurement matrices with small restricted isometry constants $\delta_{2s}<1/3$. A weaker condition $\delta_{2s} < 0.6246$ is actually sufficient to guarantee stable and robust recovery of all $s$-sparse vectors via $l_1$-minimization. In Hilbert space a random linear map satisfies a general RIP with high probability and allow recovering and extending many known compressive sampling results. In this session, I provide a comprehensive introduction to CS. This thesis extends the known restricted isometric projection of sparse datasets in Euclidean spaces $\mathbb{R}^N$ down into low-dimensional subspaces $\mathbb{R}^k, k \ll N,$ to the case of low-dimensional varieties $\mathcal{M} \subset \mathbb{R}^N,$ of codimension $N - k = \omega(N)$. Applications to structured/hierarchical datasets are considered.

item.title: [Talk] Darboux transformation and soliton equations
item.description:
Title: Darboux transformation and soliton equations.
Speaker: Yehui Huang (North China Electric Power University).
Date: Thursday, February $20^{th}$
Time: 11:00am
Place: CIS 1045
Abstract: In this talk, I will introduce a transformation originated by Darboux in his study of the linear Sturm-Liouville problem. By generalized Darboux transformations, I will present a solution formula with multiple parameters for some soliton equations, including KdV and NLS. After taking special choices for the seed solution and the eigenfunctions, different types of exact solutions are derived, which include solitons, breathers and rogue wave solutions.

item.title: Old Talks IV
item.description:
Title: Modeling Physical Phenomenon: A derivation and exploration of Laplacian growth.
Speaker: Nathan Hayford.
Date: Thursday, August $29^{th}$
Time: 3:30pm
Place: CMC 109
Abstract: Often the most interesting mathematical problems are physically motivated: Laplacian growth is no exception. However, one may wonder how such models are derived, i.e., what is their physical relevance, what constitutes a good balance between an easily solvable problem and a physically realistic one, among other questions. In this talk, I plan on deriving Laplacian growth from first principles physics, and explain the original motivations of the equation (in short, modeling a 2D fluid domain’s expansion/retraction as fluid is pumped in/out from above). I will briefly discuss the integrable structure of Laplacian growth, and how it leads to exact solutions of the equation; finally, if time permits, I will mention another modern application of Laplacian growth in condensed matter theory: the integer quantum Hall effect.\

Title: Banach Algebra Approach to Wiener’s Theorem.
Speaker: Raymond Centner.
Date: Thursday, August $15^{th}$
Time: 2:00pm
Place: CMC 108
Abstract: The Banach algebra setting can be very natural and useful in harmonic analysis. In 1932, Norbert Wiener proved that the space of absolutely convergent Fourier series is inverse closed, i.e., if f is a non-vanishing continuous function on the circle with an absolutely convergent Fourier series, then 1/f has an absolutely convergent Fourier series. Roughly ten years later, Israel Gelfand proved this result using the theory of Banach algebras. The purpose of this talk is to present this theorem in the context of Banach algebras, shedding light on the usefulness of abstraction in classical analysis.\

Title: What is ... the inverse scattering transform?
Speaker: Fudong Wang.
Date: Thursday, August $8^{th}$
Time: 3:30pm
Place: CMC 108
Abstract: The story begins after the paper about a method for solving the KdV equation by Gardner, Greene, Kruskal, and Miura (GGKM) at 1967. That’s a first example of using IST to solve a nonlinear integrable equation. In 1968, Lax found an operator way to generalize GGKM’s method, which we now called “Lax pair”. In 1971, Zakharov and Shabat use Lax’s method to solve the NLS equation. In 1974, Ablowitz, Kaup, Newell, and Segur (AKNS) compare GGKM, Lax and ZS’s method in nonlinear PDEs with the Fourier transform in the linear PDEs and the term “inverse scattering transform” was born. In this talk, we will briefly discuss how the inverse scattering transform works on solving the NLS equation. If time allows, we will also talk about how to use IST to generate the beautiful “soliton” wave solution.\

Title: A Theorem of Radó Type for the p-Laplace equation in the Heisenberg group
Speaker: Zachary Forrest.
Date: Wednesday, August $8^{th}$
Time: 11:00am
Place: CMC 108
Abstract: It is known that in Euclidean spaces, the p-Laplace equation possesses a Radó-type result: That is, given a domain $\Omega \subseteq \mathbb{R}^n$ and a fixed exponent $1<\texttt{p}<\infty$, a function $u \in C^1(\Omega)$ which is a viscosity solution to the $\texttt{p}$- Laplace equation $$-\Delta_\texttt{p}u=0 ,,,, (1)$$ in the set is also viscosity solution solution to Equation (1) in $\Omega$. This result was proven in a paper (2005) of Juutinen and Lindqvist via the use of the Implicit Function Theorem, and motivated by this approach and the works of Franchi-Serapioni-Serra Cassano (2007) & Bieske (2006) we prove a removability result for $\texttt{p}$-harmonic functions in the first Heisenberg group $\mathbb{H}_1$.

Title: A Survey of the Polynomial Method.
Speaker: Austin Dukes.
Date: Thursday, August $1^{st}$
Time: 3:30pm
Place: CMC 13
Abstract: Recently, we have seen a surge of progress on many long-standing problems from various fields using methods based on ... polynomials? Based on relatively simple combinatorial arguments and dimension-counting from linear algebra, these polynomial methods were not initially perceived to be especially insightful. However, applying polynomials has shed light on subtle yet essential structure in many problems spanning many areas, and these methods are currently an exciting and active area of research. In this talk, we will discuss the Polynomial Method as well as give various examples of its use in fields such as incidence geometry, harmonic analysis, and computer science.\

Title: Deep Learning.
Speaker: Roshan Warman.
Date: Thursday, July $25^{th}$
Time: 3:30pm
Place: CMC 13
Abstract: Deep Learning has received an increasing amount of attention in recent years due to its break-through applications in many fields. In this presentation, we present an exposition to the intellectual enterprises of Neural Networks, building them ground up from simple decision-making models, and provide an overview on basic machine learning algorithms, with the eventual goal to discuss more mathematically involved theorems and areas of research in statistical learning theory. The only pre-requisites are basic foundations of Analysis.

Title: Geometric group theory as a mathematical melting pot.
Speaker: Lina Fajardo Gomez.
Date: Thursday, July $18^{th}$
Time: 3:30pm
Place: CMC 13
Abstract: Geometric group theory is an area that studies discrete groups through the connections between algebraic properties of the groups and the topological and geometric properties of the spaces they act on. It is a relatively new area of study that remains very active (as demonstrated by the many conferences in the field and programs that focus on it). This seminar talk is intended as a broad introduction to geometric group theory, with examples of how it relates to different areas of mathematics, and a motivation for its study.\

Title: Some fundamental formulas on the Cauchy-type integrals.
Speaker: Fudong Wang.
Date: Thursday, July $11^{th}$
Time: 3:30pm
Place: CMC 13
Abstract: In the theory of boundary value problems of analytic functions, Cauchy-type integrals play a fundamental role. There are several fundamental formulas in the field, such like Sokhotsky-Plemelj formula, Poincaré-Bertrand formula, Plemelj-Privalov theorem, and Marcel Riesz’s inequality on the Hilbert transform. In this seminar talk, we will start from the beginning to prove some of the mentioned theorems. Those theorems are frequently applied in the theory of Riemann-Hilbert problem, Random matrices and integrable systems.\

Title: Computing the Regulator of a Real Quadratic Order Using p-Adic Methods.
Speaker: Will Youmans.
Date: Thursday, June $27^{th}$
Time: 3:30pm
Place: CMC 13
Abstract: The regulator of a real quadratic order is defined as the logarithm of the generator of the unit group (called the fundamental unit). This value is closely tied to the class number and describes the "density" of the units. The coefficients of the fundamental unit can become very large, so rather than directly compute the regulator from the fundamental unit itself we typically use a power product representation of units derived from a generating set of relations for the class group. Existing methods for computing the regulator from this data suffer from a variable loss of precision which can be difficult to control. We propose a p-adic method which simplifies the management of the precision throughout the computation.\

Title: What Can Random Matrices Do For You? Speaker: Nathan Hayford.
Date: Thursday, June $20^{th}$
Time: 3:30pm
Place: CMC 13
Abstract: Random matrix theory has been an indispensable tool for mathematical physicists for the past few decades, but one may wonder how relevant it is outside of this field. In this talk, I plan on explaining the basics of random matrices, and how they have been used in fields such as knot theory, graph combinatorics, number theory, biology, quantum gravity, integrable systems, orthogonal polynomials, and... you get the point. If time permits (and depending on the audience), I’ve also prepared some more detailed examples of how random matrix theory is used in each of these contexts. I’ll try and share as many of these as I can in the allotted time.\

Title: The presentation of the Braid group and faithfulness of its Burau representation.
Speaker: Louis Arenas.
Date: Thursday, June $13^{th}$
Time: 3:30pm
Place: CMC 13
Abstract: The talk will be centered on familiarizing the audience with the geometric braid group and it’s presentation. From here, we will see for a particular representation, for what parameters it will be faithful.

item.title: Old Talks III
item.description:
Title: An Introduction to Viscosity Solutions to the p-Laplace Equation for Constant Exponent $1<\text{p}<\infty$.
Speaker: Zachary Forrest.
Date: Tuesday, October $1^{st}$
Time: 2:00pm
Place: CMC 109
Abstract: We explore Crandall, Ishii, and Lyon’s notion of solutions in the viscosity sense for degenerate elliptic equations; after preliminaries, we will focus on viscosity solutions for the equation $$\label{Zach} \tag{$\star$} -\Delta_{\text{p}} u := \text{div}\left( |\nabla u|^{\text{p} -2} \nabla u \right) = 0$$ posed in bounded domains $\Omega \subset \mathbb{R}^n$. Essential properties of this family of solutions will be introduced, and we shall also draw comparisons with the more classical notion of weak solutions. Finally, we shall introduce Juutinen, Lindqvist, and Manfredi’s (2001) result regarding the equivalence of weak and viscosity solutions to Equation .

Title: An Introduction to the Riemann-Hilbert Problems on the real line.
Speaker: Fudong Wang.
Date: Thursday, September $26^{th}$
Time: 2:00pm
Place: CMC 109
Abstract: In this talk, we will briefly discuss what is the Riemann-Hilbert Problem(RHP). We will focus on the situation where the contour is real line. Then formulate the RHP in $L^2$-space (hopefully). The Sokhotski-Plemelj formula (or Cauchy operator) plays a fundamental role in the theory of RHP, from where we can see the connection between the singular integral equation and the RHP. A solution method, via the Cauchy operator, will also be introduced (hopefully). Finally, we will discuss how does RHP connect to the MKdV equation.\

Title: Rational Solutions to the Painlevé II equation.
Speaker: Nathan Hayford.
Date: Thursday, September $19^{th}$
Time: 2:00pm
Place: CMC 109
Abstract: The Painlevé II (PII) equation appears in many problems in theoretical physics, combinatorics, and random matrix theory. However, being a non-linear equation, solutions can be difficult to construct. One may wonder if there is a way to construct new solutions from old ones, and in fact there is. We discuss the Bäcklund transformation structure of PII with an explicit example: a family of rational solutions to this equation.\

Title: Connections between ladder operators and representation theory (Part II)
Speaker: Louis Arenas.
Date: Thursday, September $12^{th}$
Time: 2:00pm
Place: CMC 109
Abstract: Continuing the talk from last Thursday, using the machinery developed last time; there will be an explicit connection to spin states of a particle.

item.title: Old Talks II
item.description:
Title: Algebraic number theory and the ideal class group.
Speaker: Will Youmans.
Date: Tuesday, November $26^{th}$
Time: 2:00pm
Place: CMC 109
Abstract: Over three and a half centuries ago Fermat posed his famous Last Theorem. Attempts to prove the theorem stimulated the development of algebraic number theory throughout the $19^{th}$ century. We will give an introduction to concepts in algebraic number theory from a historical perspective with the aim of motivating the ideal class group.
Title: Euler’s $\zeta(2)$ and $\zeta(4)$ and other related series by means of trigonometric integrals.
Speaker: Cezar Lupu.
Date: Tuesday, November $21^{st}$
Time: 2:00pm
Place: CMC 109
Abstract: In this talk, we shall illustrate how we can make use of trigonometric integrals such as $$\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin^n(x) dx, \quad \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \tan^n(x) dx$$ for derivation of Euler’s $\zeta(2)$ and $\zeta(4)$ formulas. On the other hand, we also obtain Leibniz’s alternating series for $\log 2$ and $\frac{\pi}{4}$.
Title: Geometry, Links, and Magnetism.
Speaker: Nathan Hayford.
Date: Thursday, November $14^{th}$
Time: 2:00pm
Place: CMC 109
Abstract: The linking number is a well-known invariant in topology, and has been around since the time of Gauss. We will discuss this invariant, and how it may be computed via purely geometric means. Furthermore, we investigate Gauss’ original motivations and intuition for the linking number in the theory of magnetism. Finally, if time permits, we mention how other topological invariants (like the Jones polynomial) can be computed (in a surprisingly similar manner) via appropriate topological field theories.
Title: Rogue wave solutions to the nonlocal nonlinear Schrodinger equation.
Speaker: Rusuo Ye.
Date: Thursday, October $17^{th}$
Time: 2:00pm
Place: CMC 109
Abstract: By using a matrix version of Darboux transformation with a spectral matrix of the Jordan block form, rogue wave solutions to the nonlocal nonlinear Schrödinger (NLS) equation are presented. General rogue wave solutions up to the fourth-order are formulated. The structure of these solutions is essentially determined by the corresponding solutions of the Lyapunov equation. With appropriate choices of free parameters, dynamics and distribution patterns for the nonlocal NLS equation are shown to be much abundant than those for the local NLS equation.\

item.title: Old Talks I
item.description:
Title: The Calderón problem.
Speaker: Lina Fajardo Gomez.
Date: Thursday, February $13^{th}$
Time: 11:00am
Place: CIS 1023
Abstract: What do oil drilling and tumor detection have in common? How could nonlinear equations be easier to work with? The Calderón problem was first introduced as an inverse boundary value problem: how information about the boundary of a domain can be used to determine information about its interior. We will discuss the set up, some applications, and a proposed solution for a class of Calderón type inverse problems.

Title: Variational Problems and How to Solve Them.
Speaker: Nathan Hayford.
Date: Thursday, February $6^{th}$
Time: 11:00am
Place: CIS 1023
Abstract: Many problems in math and physics arise as problems of extremizing some functional. Such problems include the isoperimetric problem, minimal surface problem, and the formulation of Lagrangian mechanics. We shall discuss the calculus of variations, and provide worked out examples of how these techniques may be applied to solve such problems. We will also discuss how such techniques may be applied to write Lagrangian formulations of theories like electromagnetism and general relativity, if time permits.

Title: Introduction to the Lorentz Group.
Speaker: Louis Arenas.
Date: Thursday, January $30^{th}$
Time: 11:00am
Place: CIS 1023
Abstract: The goal of this talk is to introduce the audience to the definition of the Lorentz group and motivation in general relativity. We will derive commutation relations, and if time permits show the restricted Lorentz group is isomorphic to the Möbius group.

Title: Introduction to the Riemann-Hilbert Problem in $L^p$-space.
Speaker: Fudong Wang.
Date: Thursday, January $23^{rd}$
Time: 11:00am
Place: CIS 1023
Abstract: We will first introduce some fundamental results about the Cauchy operator. Base on the Cauchy operator, we will make it precise what is the RHP and what is the solution to an RHP. Then we will talk about the two types of inhomogeneous Riemann-Hilbert problems and establish the equivalence between them. Finally, a uniqueness theorem of RHP in $L^p$ will be given. If time permits, its application to the inverse scattering theory will be mentioned too.
